questions.text: The patient’s muscle power is accessed in a patient and found to have active movement against gravity but NOT against resistance. What is the Grade according to the MRC scale?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Grade 3 Active movement against gravity but NOT against resistance.

Highyeild:

The Medical Research Council scale for grading muscle strength ● Grade 0: no contraction ● Grade 1: flicker or trace of contraction ● Grade 2: active movement with gravity eliminated ● Grade 3: active movement against gravity ● Grade 4: active movement against gravity and resistance ● Grade 5: normal power Commonly Grade 4 is divided into 4—, 4 and 4+, denoting severe, moderate and mild weakness, and some use 5- to signify minimal weakness.

questions.text: Identify the disorder from the Image:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Duchenne Muscular dystrophy Duchenne muscular dystrophy (Xp21 dystrophy): There is pseudohypertrophy of the weak muscles (e.g. the calves and deltoids) . The child is ‘ climbing up himself ’ with legs widely placed as he gets up from the sitting position to the standing position . This is Gowers’ sign.

Highyeild:

Duchenne muscular dystrophy is the most common neuromuscular disorder . It is X linked recessive in inheritance.It is due to the absence of the dystrophin gene. Characterized by progressive proximal muscle weakness ,developmental delay and intellectual impairment. Gowers sign is positive : The patient has to climb on his arms and hands to get up from the squatting position.This occurs due to weakness of proximal muscles l ike quadriceps and gluteus maximus. There is hypertrophy of calf muscles. There is associated cardiomyopathy. Diagnosis:Serum CK levels increased, PCR for dystrophin gene and muscle biopsy. Treatment: Steroid Eteplirsen :it influences the splicing machinery to skip exon 51 from the mature mRNA transcript. This restores the reading frame of DMD, allowing for successful translation of a shortened but functional dystrophin protein.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A, B , The figure is suggestive of Gower’s sign with calf hypertrophy, suggesting duchenne muscular dystrophy. Option: D. Facio Scapulo humeral disorder - involves the muscles of face and scapula, shoulder muscles. causing winging of the scapula, poly hill sign . There is an increased incidence of nerve deafness ( SNHL) and Coats’ disease, a triad of telangiectasia, exudation, and retinal detachment. Facioscapulohumeral dystrophy with prominent scapular winging.

questions.text: 60-year-old Mr.Yadav comes to the physician complaining of fatigue and muscle weakness in his extremities. He has also lost 7kg during the last 3 months. He has no other medical conditions. The patient smokes 2 packs of cigarettes daily and consumes alcohol occasionally. His muscle strength is 3/5 in the proximal muscle groups symmetrically. His reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. No sensory abnormality is present. There are lesions over the dorsum of his fingers shown below. Chest x-ray reveals an ill-defined mass in the right lower lobe His muscle weakness is most likely due to a lesion involving which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Muscle fibers This patient's smoking history, weight loss , and right lower lobe mass are concerning for lung cancer . Patients with suspected malignancy can develop a paraneoplastic syndrome . Paraneoplastic syndromes affecting the peripheral nerve and/or muscle (eg, myasthenia gravis, Lambert-Eaton syndrome, dermatomyositis ) ,most commonly present with muscle weakness , as seen in this patient .

Highyeild:

Dermatomyositis is an idiopathic inflammatory myopathy with immune-mediated muscle injury .Dermatomyositis patients typically present with symmetrical proximal muscle weakness and erythematous rash( Gottron's sign ) or raised,Violaceous,,scaly area (Gottron’s papules) on the dorsum of the fingers ( as shown in image) and/or upper eyelids (heliotrope eruption) , Rash on trunk (V sign),periungual telangiectasia. Diagnosis is usually confirmed by muscle biopsy . Autoantibodies- Anti-jo-1 Anti-mi-2:good prognosis Anti SRP-poor prognosis

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B . Peripheral nerve involvement usually causes neuropathies presenting with sensory and/or motor abnormalities and abnormal reflexes on physical examination. This patient's normal reflexes and sensory examination make this unlikely. Option: C . Myasthenia gravis due to autoantibodies against acetylcholine receptors in the postsynaptic membrane .This patient's absence of eye findings ,absence of fluctuating weakness and the presence of skin findings make this less likely. Option: D . Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome involves antibodies targeted against the presynaptic membrane. Although patients can also present with proximal limb muscle weakness, they usually have other autonomic dysfunction (eg, dry mouth, erectile dysfunction) and absent or diminished deep-tendon reflexes .

questions.text: A 45-year-old Mrs.Sharma comes to the office due to progressive weakness for the past several months. She has difficulty combing her hair and getting in and out of her car. She also reports difficulty swallowing and has had several episodes of choking while drinking water. Vital signs are within normal limits, and she has normal sensation and deep tendon reflexes. Strength is 4/5 in the deltoid and quadriceps. Physical examination is otherwise unremarkable. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 50 mm/hr, and serum creatine kinase is elevated. TSH is normal. Which of the following is the best initial treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Prednisone This patient has features of polymyositis , including chronic proximal muscle weakness, otherwise normal neurologic findings, and an elevated CK . Initial remission can be induced with glucocorticoids.

Highyeild:

Polymyositis- Peak incidence at 40-50 , women >> men . Proximal muscle weakness ( difficulty climbing stairs, getting into or out of a low chair or car, or working with the arms overhead (eg, combing hair) Involvement of upper esophageal musculature can cause dysphagia with regurgitation and aspiration. Definitive diagnosis is established on muscle biopsy showing Endomysial inflammatory infiltrate with CD8 T-cells . Initial remission can be induced with glucocorticoids (eg, prednisone), and most patients also receive a glucocorticoid-sparing agent (eg, methotrexate,azathioprine ) to minimize the long-term adverse effects of treatment.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Pyridostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor used to treat myasthenia gravis , which is characterized by weakness that worsens with activity and involves facial and distal limb muscles in addition to proximal muscles. Option: C. Riluzole is used for ALS (Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis) a progressive neurodegenerative disorder that causes asymmetric upper (spastic weakness, hyperreflexia) and lower (muscle atrophy, fasciculations) motor neuron Muscle enzymes (eg, creatine kinase) are generally normal in these conditions. Option: D. Beta interferon used in MS (Multiple Sclerosis) presents with episodic neurologic deficits in different distributions ( episodes are disseminated in space and time).

Extraedge:

Endomysial inflammatory infiltrate with CD8 T-cells is seen in polymyositis .

questions.text: A 52-year-old Mrs.Srivastva comes to the physician with a rash over her face that began a few weeks ago . Lately, the patient has also been having difficulty rising from a seated position and climbing stairs. On examination , an erythematous rash on the upper chest and violaceous periorbital edema are present . Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows symmetric proximal muscle weakness of the legs . This patient's condition is most often associated with which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Malignancy This woman with proximal muscle weakness and rash has features consistent with dermatomyositis . On the face, the eruption is most often accompanied by periorbital edema and is known as the heliotrope sign . Macular erythema plaques over anterior neck and chest ( V-sign ) . .Internal malignancies are more common in patients with dermatomyositis (>15% of adult patients) compared to the general population. The most common malignancies are ovarian, lung , pancreatic, stomach, or colorectal cancers, and non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions would not be expected to cause positive sharp waves and fibrillation potentials on electromyography (EMG)?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Myasthenia gravis Abnormal spontaneous activity on EMG ( fibrillations and positive sharp waves ) comes from irritability of the muscle membrane from denervation . In myasthenia gravis the neuromuscular junction malfunctions, but the nerve and muscle are in contact so abnormal spontaneous activity should not be present.

Highyeild:

Myasthenia gravis Myasthenia gravis due to autoantibodies against acetylcholine receptors in the postsynaptic membrane . Diagnosis of Myasthenia Gravis (MG) History Diplopia, ptosis, dysarthria, dysphagia, dyspnea Weakness in characteristic distribution: proximal limbs, neck extensors, generalized Fluctuation and fatigue: worse with repeated activity, improved by rest Effects of previous treatments Physical examination Evaluation for ptosis at rest and following one minute of exercise, extraocular muscles and subjective diplopia, orbicularis oculi and oris strength, jaw opening and closure Assessment of muscle strength in neck and extremities Weakness following repeated shoulder abduction Vital capacity measurement Absence of other neurologic signs Laboratory testing Anti-AChR radioimmunoassay: ~85% positive in generalized MG; 50% in ocular MG; definite diagnosis if positive; negative result does not exclude MG; ~40% of AChR antibody-negative patients with generalized MG have anti-MuSK antibodies Repetitive nerve stimulation: decrement of >10% at 3 Hz: highly probable Single-fiber electromyography: blocking and jitter, with normal fiber density; confirmatory, but not specific Edrophonium chloride (Enlon®) 2 mg + 8 mg IV; highly probable diagnosis if unequivocally positive For ocular or cranial MG: exclude intracranial lesions by CT or MRI Abbreviations: AChR, acetylcholine receptor; CT, computed tomography; MRI, magnetic resonance imaging; MuSK, muscle-specific tyrosine kinase.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A, D . The connection between the muscle and the nerve can be damaged either by axon loss , as is the case in neuropathies such as diabetes, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), or carpal tunnel syndrome. Option: C. The connection can also be lost in cases of myopathy, such as inclusion body myositis, where inflammation in the muscles disconnects the motor neuron from the muscle membrane.

questions.text: A 47-year-old Mrs. Chatterjee is evaluated for an onset over 2 to 3 weeks for low-grade , intermittent fever; blanching of the second and third right fingertips in response to cold exposure; cracking and peeling of the skin on the sides of the Second digits and palms . Pain and swelling of the second and fourth PIP joints bilaterally. She does not take any medications. Tips of the digits are cool without discoloration. Erythema of the malar area, forehead, and chin is present. Pulmonary examination reveals crackles at the lung bases. There is no weakness. Lab shows CK -115U/L , Anti ds DNA and anti-smith antibodies are negative , Anti-jo 1 is positive , ANA titre is 1:1258 . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Antisynthetase syndrome The most likely diagnosis is anti-synthetase syndrome , as the patient is showing an abrupt onset of Raynaud phenomenon , crackles at base of lung( Interstitial Lung disease ), low grade fever, pain and swelling of PIP joints .

Highyeild:

Antisynthetase syndrome- characterized by interstitial lung disease , myositis , Raynaud phenomenon, non-erosive inflammatory arthritis , constitutional findings such as low-grade fever , and mechanic's hands . It’s very difficult to treat. Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) are often positive in patients with antisynthetase syndrome, but anti- Jo-1 antibodies are more specific for the diagnosis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Sjogren syndrome - Constitutional finding and inflammatory arthritis are common.,But Raynaud phenomenon is less . Dry eyes and dry mouth are most common presenting symptoms. anti-Ro/SSA and anti-La/SSB are positive . Option: C. SLE -Fever, Raynaud phenomenon, Rash, inflammatory arthritis and positive ANA are seen in SLE. However, abrupt onset rare ly occurs, mechanic’s hands are not a feature and anti-Jo antibodies are not characteristic. Option: D. Systemic sclerosis -fever and inflammatory arthritis are far less likely. Raynaud phenomenon is very common in systemic sclerosis. The finding of either localized /diffuse skin tightening and thickening including sclerodactyly are absent in this patient. Mechanic’s hand is not a feature and anti-Jo antibodies are not characteristic.

questions.text: A 67 year old man comes with weakness, and difficulty with handwriting, which is not as neat as in the past. He reports no muscle cramping. He takes no medications. There is no rash. There is symmetric weakness of the forearm and thigh muscles. Reduced grip strength and reduced wrist and finger flexion are noted. There is atrophy of the muscles of the forearms and interosseous muscles of the right hand greater than the left. There are no fasciculations. Labs show a CK level of 900 U/L. EMG shows myopathic changes in the proximal and distal muscles of the extremities .What is most likely diagnosis ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Inclusion body myositis The most likely diagnosis Is Inclusion body myositis (IBM) - as reduced grip strength,reduced wrist and finger flexion is mentioned in the question suggesting distal muscle weakness >proximal muscle weakness, suggesting Inclusion Body Myositis.

Highyeild:

Inclusion body myositis an inflammatory myopathy that can involve both the proximal and distal muscles ; although typically symmetrical , muscle distribution may be asymmetric. Sporadic IBM is the most common muscle disease in elderly populations, men >> women ,and typically develops after age 50 years a nd does not appear to affect Individuals younger than 45 years old. Distal muscle involvement helps to distinguish IBM from other inflammatory myopathies . CK levels can be normal or only slightly elevated (usually <10 times normal). Endomysial inflammatory infiltrates with cytoplasmic inclusions and rimmed vacuoles is seen on muscle biopsy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. ALS(Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis) can be distinguished from myositis by the presence of fasciculations , and ALS does not raise serum creatine kinase levels. Option: C. Polymyositis occurs before 50 , It generally presents with proximal , rather than distal muscle weakness, and serum creatine kinase levels can be substantially higher than those seen in Inclusion body myositis (IBM) , often greater than 10 to 50 times normal. Option: D. Mitochondrial myopathy can present in childhood, adolescence, or young adulthood, and a family history of myopathy is evident . serum Creatine kinase normal AND lactate is elevated .

questions.text: A 63-year-old man is evaluated for a 2-month history of progressive lower extremity weakness. He reports increased difficulty arising from a chair, climbing stairs, and reaching overhead. He was diagnosed with polymyositis 6 months ago. prednisone and azathioprine were initiated at that time, with clinical improvement. He currently takes prednisone, 20 mg/d, and azathioprine 100 mg/d. On physical examination.The patient cannot arise from the chair without using his arms to push off and can squat only by using his hands to hold on to the chair. He has cushingoid features and scattered ecchymoses on the forearms. Laboratory studies show a serum creatine kinase level of 160 U/L. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Reduce prednisone dose The most appropriate management is reduction of the prednisone dose in this patient with drug-induced myopathy caused by glucocorticoids.

Highyeild:

Glucocorticoid myopathy is a common consequence of prolonged treatment with high-dose glucocorticoids, as seen in this patient treated for polymyositis . History is suggestive of glucocorticoid myopathy when a patient has been started on high-dose glucocorticoids within a few months, has cushingoid features . and has normal serum creatine kinase levels the initial clinical improvement and reduction in the muscle enzymes with reduction in glucocorticoid dose most strongly suggest drug-induced myopathy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Electromyography (EMG) - No single feature is diagnostic on electromyogram (EMG). Weakness can often be addressed by reducing the glucocorticoid dose and following the patient over the next 3 to 4 weeks to assess for gains in strength. Option: B. Muscle biopsy is an invasive procedure that is not indicated in a patient in whom initial clinical improvement and normalization of muscle enzyme levels has occurred. suggesting the diagnosis of glucocorticoid- induced myopathy. Option: C. Reducing the azathioprine dose is not likely to be of diagnostic or therapeutic benefit because proximal muscle weakness is not an adverse effect of azathioprine.
